caption: You probably know us as Environment Canada, but we’ve been Environment and Climate Change Canada for almost a year now. What do we do? Sure, we give you your weather info so you can plan your days, but we do so much more than that! Stay tuned and find out what we’re all about. We’re giving you access to exclusive behind-the-scenes photos and videos from teams located across our beautiful country.

“Being biologists, we were out looking for great blue herons again this summer. By visiting nesting sites, we can monitor these awesome birds and track the species. Sadly, their numbers are declining, so we’re learning all we can!” – Kate and Britney, CWS Crew

“Approaching Sand Heads, a weather station off Vancouver Island in the Georgia Strait. Sometimes, I go on familiarization trips as a meteorologist, for example, to replace and calibrate weather sensors. To do that, I hop into a hovercraft with the Canadian Coast Guard! You’re jealous, I know! In the background, one of our monitoring technicians and three coast guards unload our equipment onto the platform.” – Cindy YU, MSC Crew

“Puffin Patrol to the rescue! This young puffin (on the right), found near the Witless Bay Ecological Reserve, NL, was drawn ashore by bright lights from nearby communities at night. We band and measure the rescued puffins before releasing them back in to the ocean.” - Sabina, CWS Crew
Spotted: Our mini van on a field trip for bird conservation to the beautiful Lac du Bois grasslands.
"Monday got me like" Burrowing Owl caught by one of our Infrared motion-sensor cameras. Our biologists use the cameras to take images in wildlife habitats across Canada.

Meet Lynne (l), and Barbara (r). Both women were part of the first all-female Canadian Wildlife Service research team back in , bird banding in the Arctic. years later, Barbara continues her work with CWS. This month, you will find her on Manitoulin Island counting Sandhill Cranes.
We spotted this oddball heron and her mate nesting on a pylon while surveying the heron population in the Fraser River, BC. Must be something to it, they raised a chick there!

Here is a photo of the Automated Weather Station taken in the Callaghan valley near Whistler last March, while the sun was still coming up over the mountains and the hoar frost is on the snow. Automated weather stations like this one near Whistler, BC provide weather data for more accurate forecasting!

“It is good to have an end to journey toward; but it is the journey that matters, in the end.” – Ursula K. Le GuinDr. Fred Roots had quite the journey, and we owe him a lot. He lived a life full of eloration and discovery, and he played an influential role in the development of Environment Canada. From organizing the Polar Continental Shelf Program to chairing the UNESCO Man and the Biosphere Programme, his accomplishments were many. Dr. Roots is also known for his contribution in writing the Antarctic Treaty—a treaty whose legacy lives on today. He will always be remembered.:

Shine bright like a lighthouse…er diamond?Many weather stations are remote. With the Pachena Light Station in the background, a Coast Guard helicopter near Bamfield, B.C. safely delivers our weather station technicians to their workplace, a weather station along the world famous West Coast Trail.
“I AM A MAGICAL OWL DELIVERING A MESSAGE: HOOOOO!” A burrowing owl trying really hard to be a spooky hoot. Happy owl-ween!

This winter, we are going to live vicariously through these whimbrels as they set their sights on warmer wintering grounds.Working with partners, we’ve equipped these migratory birds with transmitters to track their journey from Miscou Island in New Brunswick, Canada, to Brazil. Knowing where they are going and how fast they are travelling can give biologists a better idea of what sort of threats they might be facing during their travels.

Here we are, four biologists (two in front, one way in the back, and yours truly behind the camera), installing a fence through a small tree-lined wetland at the Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area (NWA), Saskatchewan. We need fences like this one to keep our local “vegetation managers”() from wandering off the NWA and onto the roads and neighbouring properties. They munch away to keep our grasslands healthy! It took a lot of elbow grease to install this -km fence. We worked on it in our spare time, over about months, and we had to start bright and early to avoid the blistering summer heat. (Hipwaders are hot at the best of times.) But at least we had the mosquitos to keep us company! - Kerry

COOL SCIENTIST ALERT! Here’s Benoit, one of our biologists studying the health of freshwater in Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, using *CABIN methodology. By sampling and studying invertebrates, he can tell a lot about how healthy the freshwater is. *CABIN is the Canadian Aquatic Biomonitoring Network, a network of groups working together to assess the health of freshwater ecosystems across Canada. In using CABIN methods, partners take observations using approved protocols and make scientific assessments using national standards.

Good news comes on Friday! The Randle Reef Sediment Remediation Project is cleaning up Hamilton Harbour. Yay clean water! The engineered containment facility (or ECF) pictured here acts like a box that will store the yuckiest of sediment. When the $138.9 million project is complete in , it will make the water cleaner for the fish & us to enjoy, and bring jobs and tourism to the local community. Hooray!!!!! : Bermingham Foundation Solutions
“Have you seen a bear? It’s ! Yeah … hugging a bear is a little dangerous (understatement!) … unless it’s Yogi or Winnie the Pooh. But I’m just a cute caribou! Can I get a hug?”

“It’s getting hot in here” or is it just this carefully planned grassland fire? Biologist and Fireboss Kerry stands to watch as her colleague Sarah steps back from the flames while lighting up the primary fireline – Woah!!! A controlled burn can help keep ecosystems healthy by reducing the number of shrubs and trees, & removing old plant material that builds up over years.

Hello, Henry here. Our Climate Change crew is in Marrakech for (Conference of the Parties). I’ll be sharing photos of what it’s like to be part of the Canadian delegation and highlights of the work we do.

Meet Sue, a water scientist who studies harmful algal blooms, at our lab in Burlington. She has always been inspired by her work. “The diversity of field work and lab work has given me an exciting career in science.” Here she is on her home-away-from-home, the Canadian Coast Guard Ship Limnos. Sue will be retiring in December, and we wish her all the best!

Oh BUOY! What a boat! Come on board! The Canadian Coast Guard Ship (CCGS) Limnos calls Burlington, Ontario, its home, where it is docked at the Canada Centre for Inland Water (more often than knot). Puns are totally intended. Taking its name from “limnology,” the study of inland waters, CCGS Limnos is the dedicated scientific vessel for our environmental research and monitoring on the Great Lakes. It is capable of sampling the water, using a wide array of equipment, and it is equipped with an on-board laboratory for the processing and analysis of samples. How neat is that?

"How many negotiators and eerts can we fit in this very small space? This is the dell office where all the magic happens. This is where the delegation meets with other countries, reviews proposals and discusses path forward on ! ". - Henry المغرب مراكش

"I took an electric bus to the venue today. It's great to see climate-friendly options to get around, especially when there are so many people attending COP." - Henry

I had a chance to check out the “This is the Arctic” video about the effects of in the Arctic yesterday at the village. A pretty cool, immersive eerience showing different landscapes and communities. -Henry

Here's my colleague and friend Pierre-Jonathan (or PJ), representing in the plenary hall at . He works on climate finance, which helps developing countries to address the impacts of , deploy clean energy technology, and manage natural resources sustainably. – Henry

He has led more than eeditions to the Regions, as well as numerous other journeys to many fascinating and remote corners of the Planet - WOAH! (We envy him too!) Geoff is one of the speakers at the National Summit on . Follow the link in our bio to get the deets about how to participate online.

Rainbows were everywhere this summer on the barrengrounds! We kept eecting unicorns 🦄 too; we got barren-ground caribou instead...

New! National Area: Scott IslandsThe Scott Islands and surrounding waters together make up one of the most productive and biologically diverse marine , particularly for , on the Canadian Pacific Coast.

These good looking birds are known for their stoic stature and epic appearance - from Southern California to the coastal Alaskan Arctic. Tens of thousands of Tufted Puffins choose the Scott Islands as their preferred breeding grounds when taking a beak break from a lifetime at sea.Everyday I’m puffi-lin. : Greg Jones
It’s not the magic school bus but it’s still a pretty awesome bus! This Canadian fuel-cell-powered is already being used in Foshan, & emits - WOAH! Ideas like this will shape the future of !

Common Murre, Pelagic Cormorant and Tufted mingling on this typical rock-face nesting habitat, where various platforms, holes, and crevices become ideal nest sites between trips offshore to feed.Puffin’ cute!

“Hi there, we’re two brand new sanderling checking in from the Great White North. We may only be a few hours old, but we are ready to go! Don’t worry, mom and dad are close by as we get our vitals taken. But first, we’ll get a few leg bands that will help track our progress as we migrate south for the . Soon we’ll be soaking up the sun ️on the Florida coast. You may have met our famous cousin, ? Her plumage is a little different from ours, but that’s because we need to blend into the arctic tundra to keep predators at bay. We can’t wait to grow into those beautiful silvery feathers, and to snack on some yummy clams on our own to a sunny beach. Surf’s up!”

Did you know that the industry is growing at a breakneck speed? The result: creating jobs for the middle class and growing the Canadian clean economy! To support this growth, the Government of Canada has partnered with the provinces and territories to implement a Pan-Canadian Framework on and .

prefer habitats close to water, and wetlands for shore But a surprising number of birds can be found in dry or rocky habitats like the one here. Here is Lara (aco-op program student) taking photos of the landscape after we finished surveying the plot.

…err.. Here! December st marked the start of meteorological . In winter, light interacting with crystals can create a variety of atmospheric optic phenomena, including parhelia, also known as . Preeeetttyyyyy!
Our friends from will be in National Park for the next days filming the effects of on the Athabasca . How cool?!

Can you guess what this is? . . . . .It’s special because It wasn’t cut by one of our scientists... Freshwater lake ice is very brittle and breaks into small discs like this one. Our scientists take the discs from the ice corer in the correct order, and accurately reconstruct its ice growth history. Fascinating, isn’t it?

!  Chris spends his work day taking measurements to compare with satellite data in prime bear territory across the Canadian - WOAH! He studies the , the frozen part of the Earth's surface, including the cover, sea ice, and frozen ground, as well as its role in the climate system.
Here’s another cool arctic climate action shot of Chris,this time. recording the size, shape, and type of snow grains for each layer of the snowpack using a field microscope. CanEnvironment
How a ️ sees a surveyor…probably. much? Impressive!
would be proud of our crew’s culinary skills in the field! Trail Valley Creek camp kitchen kept everyone fed and supplied with warm drinks.Bon appetit!
Another action shot of Chris, braving the cold to auger a hole through the ice on Sitidgi Lake, , to measure ice thickness.

“Our Inuit guides built this igloo, seen here framed in the Northern Lights. You can see our main work tools: an ice auger and shovel, leaning up against the outside of the igloo .” - Arvids, Climate Scientist This photo was taken during a research trip to Lake Tunusualuk, , in northern Quebec.
Spotted: Climate scientist Peter, cutting ice cores out of a lake to study its structure -- bubble content,layers, density, and thickness, near Puvirnituq, Nunavik.

During their journey across the and , our climate research crew take coordinated snow measurements.They found that snow cover was made up of different sized crystals with small fractions of new, recent, and icy snow. The snow was shallow (<40 cm deep), usually with fewer than six layers. Here’s one of their stops at Trail Valley Creek, Mackenzie River Delta Region, Northwest Territories.
!Thanks to researchers at the Dr. Neil Trivett Global Atmosphere Watch Lab in Alert, Nunavut! You’ve helped us better understand our North, & pollutant transport for years.

might know nothing, but our and research crew is full of knowledge! The team crossed the and by to take systematic snow measurements in regions for the first time. These new measurements, combined with measurements previously-made, indicate the tundra snow region stretches more than km across Arctic and subarctic North America. Here’s their camp in a valley near Aberdeen Lake, . Careful, there might be …
Is this a photo of Santa’s village? No it’s our Alert Lab built in where scientists monitors background concentrations of trace gases, aerosols, and organic pollutants.
Basked in sunrise glow! Our Dr. Neil Trivett Global Atmosphere Watch Lab in Alert, Nunavut has been monitoring the atmosphere for the last years.
Step inside our Alert Observatory in Nunavut! Scientists have been working there for years providing Greenhouse gases () and atmospheric data.

alert! Our research scientists mapped snow depth using self-recording GPS depth probes. The depth probe was powered by rechargeable batteries and was linked to a data-logger and GPS antenna unit carried by the snow-surveyor in a backpack.
How stunning is this?!Morning glow outside our Alert Lab in Nunavut. NaturePhotography

A scientist on a multi-kilometre snow transect across tundra snow. These on-the-ground measurements help scientists better understand the characteristics of snow. The data collected is used to refine computer models used to predict climate change. CanEnvironment
Two climate scientists touch down to do snow surveys near Eureka,. This was just one stop in an international research project to findout how and snow properties differ.

Tag a friend who can’t compete with puffins! The Tufted spends most of its life at sea, coming to land only to breed during a few critical months. Puffins are powerful flyers, beating their wings -400 times a minute to achieve speeds up to kph (40 mph). That would have just about any human puff-in through the day. : Catherine Jardine, Birds Studies Canada
!Our Dr Neil Trivett Global Atmosphere Watch Lab in Alert, Nunavut was named to honour this man (1943-2002) who founded it in .
Here are cool photos of our Alert lab.The lab was built in ’86, eanded in ‘92 and houses programs from + international research institutions. FLABBERGASTING! We know!.
Can you identify that bird? .......
They see me rollin’ These ducks were perfectly happy and just kept swimming in Alaksen National wildlife Area last fall.

: This was the Ontario Weather Centre computer room at the Pearson Airport Malton weather officeAt the time, forecast maps were hand drawn by forecasters and sent via big scanners on the "digital" facsimile circuits to other weather centres. :John Botari •••

Despite having the latest in technology, meteorologists still perform a hand analysis of weather maps daily at the Prairie and Arctic Storm Prediction Centre in Edmonton. Colouring is one of the best parts of the job!

Here is one of the most deceptively delightful predators in : The Fisher.Fishers are among the most effective land carnivores, especially given their size. Porcupine is their favourite prey! That’s one prickly meal.Here we see one hopping over and marking our bait stick (the scent glands are located in the rear). Then it’s off to investigate our camera as they click away.

We use motion-sensor cameras to photograph wildlife in their natural habitats. 🦅🦌🦊Turns out, our bait stick is quite popular with all species, be they winged, pawed, or hooved! Keep checking for our great candid shots of Canadian wildlife.•••

Look deep into nature, and then you will understand everything better. –Albert EinsteinThis bear was soaking up the summer sights as much as he could. Autumn was a little less spectacular for him though, since he doesn't see much of the yellow-orange-red colour spectrum.
“It’s mine!” “No, MINE!” Two young elk are sparring with their antlers over the stick. These young’uns need to get some practice in before wrestling starts to really count!

“I’m in love! I’m in love with this stick and I don’t care who knows it!”, exclaimed this twitterpated Mule Deer.🦌 It’s fun to imagine this deer is signing its heart out, but our say she was just enjoying a snack.
It’s may seem tragic that this handsome bull will soon lose these spectacular antlers., but worry not, new and grander ones will grow.
“Shhh, I think we’ve been spotted.” These pronghorns are a keen bunch!And fast too! Only the cheetah can outrun these speed demons; good thing they’re a whole ocean away from eachother!

Pssst… If you didn’t know this by now, you should. We’re a little obsessed with owls 🦉 OWL OF EM’! (How couldn’t we?) So we just thought we would share this photo with you. A Snowy Owl hanging on a hay bale, no big thang.

! This burrowing owl is doing his best to live up to the shining example set by our good friend the Common Loon. This little bird lives in one of National Wildlife Areas across Canada, where nationally significant habitats are protected for plants, animals and humans alike.

Biologists Paul and wildlife technician Regina are lucky enough to work out of the Goose Bay office. Last February, they had the chance to visit the Inuit community of Makkovik while hosting community workshops on how to identify bird wings. This project is a Stewardship project in collaboration with Nunatsiavut Government and modeled after a project called National Harvest Survey.
Have you heard? Canada is hosting ! Yay!Mark your calendar, we already marked ours.

Morning Sunrise on the ice “It was a beautiful degree morning in Makkovik that day... During the winter months communities on the north coast of Labrador transition to for transportation within their communities. The sea ice also becomes another type of roadway linking residents with their cabins and other communities in the winter months. travel continues until the sea ice breaks up in the spring.One of the best parts of our jobs is the chance to visit the beautiful throughout Labrador! “ – Regina, CWS Crew
to an early morning in Labrador. The burns off as the continues to rise during the Breeding Bird Survey (BBS). Many warblers, thrushes and shorebirds were singing loudly that morning!
“Beautiful morning in Labrador last summer and turned into one of the warmest in many weeks! I took off my mittens and toque by stop no. …It reached a high of degrees!” – Regina, CWS Crew TheBigLand
"At the end of the day, after all of the work was complete, we got to enjoy this beautiful Labrador sunset at the cabin we were staying in for the night." Fieldwork has its perks!

Believe it or not, this dreamy landscape is Canadian! This photo was taken at Gannet Islands Ecological Reserve, Newfoundland.During July and August these islands are abuzz with activity! It is quite an amazing sight to see thousands of seabirds! It’s definitely a privilege for some of our biologists to call this place their office during the field season.
Blink and you’ll miss it! This heron did its best to snap up a snack before it got away. Glad our treats aren’t a flight risk

While this horse may think she “nose” about measuring water quantity, we like to leave it up to our eerts. Nicole, hydrographer, conducts a direct water level survey on the shores of the Homathko River, BC.

Today is the International Day of Women and Girls in Science! We have the honor to work with many female scientists, including these ! Jesse, Marianna and Sara are meteorologists working at the Prairie and Arctic Storm Prediction Centre. They graduated from the Atmospheric Science Program at the University of Alberta. Impressive right? 🤗
Two close friends: Biologist Judith Kennedy from the Canadian Wildlife Service and Carlitos and her giant Canada Warbler.

This is our home away (in Edmonton, Eastgate offices) from home (our HQ is in Gatineau, QC). The building has a gold LEED rating for human and environmental health. Canadian Wildlife Service, the Enforcement Branch, the Prairie and Arctic Storm Prediction Center, the Canadian Meteorological Aviation Center and Air Quality all work out of this building.

Let’s celebrate years of Canada. and years of nature - a part of our heritage. We want to see YOUR photos. Show us through your eyes what represents Canada’s natural heritage. Use for a chance to be featured on our feed!

Queen Maud Gulf Migratory Bird Sanctuary might not be yrs old but it is a !This beautiful region of the Canadian Arctic is an important nesting habitat for migratory birds like Ross' Goose. Covering over km2 of land and sea, this is Canada’s largest protected area! Whoa!Learning more about these national treasures is a great start to conserving them and to celebrate ! :Kiel Drake

Sable Island is often referred to as the “Graveyard of the Atlantic” because of its many shipwrecks. A migratory bird sanctuary was established on the island in , and covers the entire island, a crescent of sand extending along an east-west axis for approximately km. And you can find wild horses here too! Andrew Macfarlane

We’re here at ECCC! This was taken in in1887!We love seeing winter photos, because…what is more Canadian than a pic? Share your photos with for a chance to be featured! :Library and Archives Canada/a022473

Can you hear the mountains calling? They want to say ! That’s such a Canadian thing to say, or oversay, as well as “sorry”, which we apparently say a lot. Beautiful is the province with the highest % of protected lands! Can you guess what percentage of its total landmass is protected?

Though is said to translate from an old French word meaning "loud noises", there was nothing boisterous about this delightfully calm day on frozen Jolicure Lake in Tintamarre National Wildlife Area, located minutes from Sackville, NB and Amherst, NS. Grab your snowshoes or cross-country skis and eerience this peaceful landscape!

Citizen scientists play an important role in many of our monitoring programs and provide biologists with invaluable information!While on a recent vacation to Cuba, nature photographer and citizen scientist, Alan Chaplin, did not know the Piping Plover he was snapping photos of was extraordinary. He reported the band only to discover that this bird had outlived its average lifespan by more than times! The -year old plover was spotted near the same location our biologists banded it in . It bred on Cavendish Beach in Prince Edward Island National Park in the early s but had not been reported in over a decade. This resight is extremely useful for our scientists in understanding this at-risk species. Piping Plover continue to be marked in Canada, now with uniquely coded leg flags.

Regina, Karel, Garry, Becky, Julie and Paul were busy through the holiday season in Nova Scotia, Newfoundland and Labrador and New Brunswick collecting information about wintering birds in the area. Each year they learn a little bit about the species that decide to rough it out in some of Canada’s harshest winter climates! Stay tuned to learn more about their adventure!

It was a chilly December day in Happy Valley-Goose Bay, Labrador but Regina, a wildlife technician, was relentless to track down and count the equally brave birds that have chosen to stick it out this winter in our northern climate.

Garry, Becky and Julie visited Cape Tormentine in search of wintering birds. They trekked through the snowy forest, and strolled the seaside finding a variety of forest birds, birds of prey and marine birds. Notable among them, a wayward Eastern Meadowlark that should have been much farther south by then.

In central Labrador, near Happy Valley-Goose Bay, wildlife biologist Paul is joined by his best friend Bailey. Equipped with a much needed cup of coffee, they set out for the count on an exceptionally cold day (around ).
This carefully crafted greets Paul and Bailey along the banks of the Churchill River in Happy Valley-Goose Bay. h
Rock Doves circle the streets of Happy Valley-Goose Bay.

This guy would definitely win at !! Another 🦉 pic? Why not!?!! We tOWLd you, we just can’t get enough of them... yes OWL of THEM! This is the Western Screech-owl and he is now listed as threatened under the Species at Risk Act, due to the loss and degradation of its habitat. But, we’re getting him some help!The Government of Canada recently finalized new protection for species, marking an important step in our commitment to protecting species and biodiversity in Canada. YAY! : Joe Fuhrman
Morning sun catches the mist rising off the river on a cold day.

Our biologists spotted species of birds while on a quick stroll into the frozen wetlands of John Lusby Marsh National Wildlife Area for the Amherst, Nova Scotia Christmas Bird Count. Nearly half of them were Arctic breeding migratory birds that reach the Atlantic Provinces in winter, such as the Snow Bunting (aka the “snowflake”), Lapland Longspur, Rough-legged Hawk, as well as Glaucous and Iceland Gulls. During their short visit, the team was especially surprised to find three Short-eared Owls flying together as a group, a rare delight!...

!One of our landscape ecologists studies windbreaks and hedgerows which provide important habitat for pollinators including native Canadian bee species. Her two-year project allows us to have baseline data to see if, how, and where bee species are affected. This is long-term data is especially important in the context of climate change and land-use modification.

“It’s MY rock!” . . “No, Mine! GET OUT OF HERE!!” ... Just a couple of Northern Fulmars arguing about their resting spot on Prince Leopold Island…nothing a human couple wouldn’t do!Prince Leopold Island Sanctuary supports large numbers of four nesting species, including Thick-billed Murre, Northern Fulmar, Black-legged Kittiwake and Black Guillemot. The sanctuary is one of the most important multi-species seabird colonies in the Arctic, and is an important site for seabird research. Seabird monitoring has been ongoing since , generating one of the strongest datasets for seabird monitoring in the . YAY BIRD CONSERVATION!

We can’t BEAR all of this cuteness!!!!!!!! Polar Bear Pass is one of Canada’s largest National Wildlife Areas and features unusual diversity of for its latitude. The NWA supports at least species of birds and various species of mammals. As the name implies, Polar Bears pass through the area in spring and summer on their way to Graham Moore Bay, to the southwest, an important feeding area where they find Walrus and Ringed Seals. : Garry Donaldson...... ᓇᓄᐃᑦᐃᑎᓪᓕᖓᑕᐅᒪᔪᖃᕐᕕᖓ

Did you know? Raindrops are not tear-shaped. Using high-speed cameras, scientists have discovered that raindrops resemble the shape of a small hamburger bun!! And now we’re craving a …mmm..,sorry about that! : Mario Ouellet......

Two Arctic Wolves relaxing after a feast near Eureka Weather Station, Nunavut. “One day as I was outside and driving up near the dump outside of the station I came across these two wolves off of the runway relaxing after a meal. Seeing the stain in the fur on the one wolf was truly amazing.” – Braden, MSC crew..... : Braden Bunce

A bunch of ‘bous Deer 🦌 seen by biologists while travelling the Tibbitt to Contwoyto Winter Road to do station maintenance on song recorders.Not only do the Automated Recording Units capture bird calls, but they also record the sounds of caribou, moose, bears and other wildlife! Some of the recording stations have a wildlife camera at them too!......
Top of the morning to you! This cluster of sanderling sandpiper eggs are channeling the spirit in Nunavut, where these migratory birds nest each spring. Happy ......

A typical desk set up at the Prairie and Arctic Storm Prediction Center in Edmonton. Meteorologists work hours a day, days a week, days a year. Each shift, our meteorologists do a complete analysis of the current conditions and monitor changing weather, always ready to issue a weather warning or watch. ️️️......

Some our staff working out of Eureka and Sable Island Weather Stations participated in Earth Hour last night and sent us exclusive photos!On Sable island, they shut off all the lights in the office (There were people working in there! When the exterior office photo was taken) and residence, and turned off any excess electronics that they could. Essential monitoring equipment and exterior lights on automatic timers had to be left on. The stars were out and beautiful last night on Sable Island. Earth Hour provided extra incentive to head outside and enjoy the natural beauty of the star filled night sky.At the Eureka Weather Station in the High Arctic (80° North). We have a permanent staff of to people but during the spring/summer months Scientists and Adventurers come from all over.Some members of the Eureka Crew went outside celebrating Earth Hour to show that we are making their way towards hr daylight (April ) no candles were actually needed there! Each day they all contribute to gathering important weather and climate data that will be used to forecast weather and monitor climate change in the Arctic!......

Canadian Wildlife Service (CWS) biologist Steve Van Wilgenburg and Wildlife Tech Patrick Turgeon were working over the weekend, attaching automated recorders to trees in Greenwater Provincial Park (SK) to assist CWS monitor boreal forest bird populations. The acoustic recorders intermittently turn on and record the songs of species such as the Threatened Canada Warbler, which can then be identified by trained staff to allow biologists to determine species abundance and distribution. It also helps biologists determine which habitats are used by forest birds. CWS biologists use these recorders to go along with surveys normally conducted by trained staff primarily in the month of June.In March, access to wet areas is easier on snowshoes, and allows biologists to capture data on resident species such as grouse, owls, chickadees and woodpeckers that breed earlier than migrants returning from the tropics.......

Meet one of our ARUs! ARU stands for Automated Recording Unit and it records the sounds birds make! The unit has an SD card which can record hours of sound! . ARUs are waterproof because they are left out for a whole year! Life in the north can be hard for these machines… bears and moose like to remove the foam microphone covers or try and open the units, and in this case, the jack pine tree it’s on has covered it in sap... .....

Rhiannon is installing a to help the Automated Recording Unit operate year-round to record bird calls. .Maintaining the stations in the winter is much more cost effective, because there are winter roads (ice roads) in the Northwest Territories! Not only do the recordings tell us what birds are present, but we also learn when birds arrive to the north in the spring and when they depart for warmer southern locations. As well, there are some bird calls which are difficult for the human ear to pick up, especially if other birds are calling at the same time (e.g. Ruffed Grouse); these units allow us to record ALL the sounds, including the tricky quiet ones .....

More ptarmigan please! So puffy, fluffy, and cute! This is a Willow Ptarmigan. On this one you can really see its feathered feet. In addition to helping keep their feet warm, they are also good for walking on snow!.....
Our friends on got a little ... they will have fun getting that paper out of the Campbell-Stokes recorder (Sunshine ️ recorder)

This Semipalmated , was banded in June at Fish Island in the Mackenzie Delta, Northwest Territories just outside the Kendall Island Migratory Bird Sanctuary. The bird was first spotted that fall on southward migration at Marco Island, Florida by Dave Addison who was doing surveys of Florida’s beaches. The bird was inadvertently given the name “Smile”… and it has stuck! Smile has since visited the same stretch of beach on nearly every spring (northward) and fall (southward) migration! He was last seen fueling up for the rest of his southbound migration at Marco Island this past fall. We can’t wait to hear if Smile is seen again on Marco Island this April! These photos of “Smile” can’t help but make one smile! Smiling Face With Smiling Eyes .......

“Holding this pendant made of elephant ivory and sea turtle shell, I can’t help but reflect on the majesty of these animals. It is amazing to see these animals in the wild and heartbreaking to see illegal trade continue in these endangered species.” Enforcement officers like Brenda, are working hard to put an end to commercial wildlife trafficking in Canada.Tap the link in our bio for more info on this enforcement case.....

Yesterday was the late Jack Miner’s birthday! Jack Miner is a Canadian pioneering conservationist.In , he founded the Jack Miner Migratory Bird Sanctuary for the conservation of then endangered migrating Canada geese and wild ducks and was one of the first to track bird migration using leg bands. To commemorate his achievements and contributions to wildlife conservation, the National Wildlife Week Act was passed in to encourage Canadians to share information and take action for wildlife conservation just like Jack Miner did. Happy birthday Jack! ..... : Library and Archives Canada / Ronny Jaques
Hello, I am a Common Loon and I represent the Canadian Wildlife Service, which is turning this year. I am so proud to be its mascot! But I need a name. Any suggestions?.....

Scientists from around agencies and institutes from all over the world are currently working together in the Arctic to measure ice on land and sea. This is one of the largest Arctic eedition ever! This huge collaborative international effort will help ensure the ice-thickness maps created from satellite data are correct. We have a small crew over there that will be sharing photos and highlights (when they have access to the Internet 🤦‍️). Check our account to follow their adventures! Photo : Pilot Troy and scientist Christian measuring the thickness of the ice to make sure it can safely support the weight of the aircraft. Photo : Justin and Josh working on a snow pit to measure snow properties on multi-year sea ice north of Alert, Nunavut.Photo : KBAL pilots preparing to land on the plane on sea ice without a prepared runway.Photo : Arvids measuring the depth of snow on sea ice along a transect. The site was accessed via aircraft.Photo : A view of the multi-year sea ice north of Alert, Nunavut.

Josh, Arvids, Andrew and Justin (University of Alberta & York University) arrived in Alert, Nunavut on Wednesday April to take part in one of the largest Arctic eedition ever! They are scheduled to depart from Alert on April. The campaign goal was to visit sites along a few ESA (European Space Agency) CryoSat orbits between Alert and N,150W and perform a full suite of snow and ice measurements at each site. By doing all this, scientists can ensure that ice-thickness maps created from satellite data are correct. Cool right? Photo : Large depth hoar crystals found within the snowpack on sea icePhoto : Justin operating the SnowMicroPen* to take very high resolution measurements of the snow layering.Photo : Cryovex sample team in their twin otter aircraft on route to a sea ice sampling site where they land directly on the ice. *A snow micro-penetrometer, measure the bonding force between snow grains/crystals at very high resolution and quite rapidly!

It’s National Volunteer Week! The Canadian Wildlife Service’s Arctic Shorebird Monitoring Program has been fortunate to have over volunteers assist with our field program over the past years! They put their lives on hold for -2 months to join us in the arctic in remote tent camps.We are celebrating by highlighting the contribution citizen scientists make to our program by introducing a volunteer each day this week.Today, meet Fletcher Smith! Fletcher is a U.S. citizen who has volunteered over months of his life coming to the tundra to help with our shorebird monitoring work. Fletcher is a special volunteer in that he also taught us how to fit Whimbrel (the bird Fletcher is holding in the photo) with tiny satellite backpacks that tell us where the birds are year round so we can have an understanding of where birds are when and what we can do to help conserve their populations......

Our National Volunteer Week highlight on the Canadian Wildlife Service’s Arctic Shorebird Monitoring Program’s volunteers continues – today meet Alvan Buckley. Alvan is a Canadian who was in between his undergrad and medical school the summer he volunteered for us. Our volunteers come from all backgrounds, ages and eeriences and in this case, we were fortunate because Alvan already had banding eerience from his other volunteer gigs. Alvan will be Dr. Alvan, MD when he joins us again this coming summer in a different part of the arctic on a different component of the Program!.....

Meet Anthony Levesque – Anthony is from Guadeloupe. He is a dedicated bird biologist with his own birding business now. In the past he was with various agencies in his home country working with hunters and government to implement protection measures for species at critical times of the year to help reduce the impact of hunting on their populations. Shorebirds look completely different in the winter – so Anthony is used to identifying them more from their shape and sound than when they are in their breeding plumage in the arctic and are easier to identify. Arctic-breeding shorebirds spend most of their life cycle outside Canada, so it is fantastic when we get to cooperate with our international colleagues. In this photo, the twin otter is loaded up and the survey team is about to head to the tundra!.....

National Volunteer Week is a special time to recognize all the people who donate their time to make our work possible. In today’s volunteer spotlight, meet Adam Fritz! Adam has volunteered two summers for the Canadian Wildlife Service’s Arctic Shorebird Monitoring Program. His background in policy is about as far as you can get from birds – until you consider that conservation takes policy work to make it happen. Adam took vacation from his federal government job to assist with monitoring birds on the tundra. That’s weeks he could have been vacationing with his family in a warm and sunny location! Not all arctic fieldwork is glamourous, in this pic we are playing cards to pass the time waiting for the fog to clear so we can get out and do our work......

Canada is home to species who are at risk due to ecosystem degradation and loss. It is up to all Canadians to work together to help protect and conserve their habitat. Today, a newly formed advisory committee met with Minister McKenna to find practical solutions for these creatures. By working together, we can safeguard the health of our Canadian wildlife and ecosystems!......

As mentioned earlier this week, the Canadian Wildlife Service’s Arctic Shorebird Monitoring Program has been fortunate to have over volunteers assist with our field program over the past years! Highlighting just five this week has been an awesome opportunity, but a big round of thanks to all of you others out there!!! Mark Dodds, seen here with a Black-bellied Plover he just fitted with a satellite backpack, is one of these awesome volunteers. Mark turned down paying jobs to come work with us for free!! His time helped us have our best field season at our study site at Nanuit Itillinga (Polar Bear Pass) National Wildlife Area in terms of number of nests found and birds banded. The satellite backpacks Mark helped deploy are allowing us to see what routes these plovers are using to migrate, where they are spending the non-breeding season and what habitats they are using. This is all important information we need to help conserve this species......

Just outside the city of Edmonton is a hidden gem called Bunchberry Meadows. This forest provides habitat for all sorts of amazing species – from moose to owls to salamanders!We are proud to announce that this forest will be conserved through our Ecological Gifts Program and the Natural Areas Conservation Program.Protecting this land will give Edmontonians the opportunity to share this space with their family for generations to come. .... . : / Kyle Marquardt : / Karol Dabbs : / Karol Dabbs

Did you know that we are responsible for managing wildlife habitats at National Wildlife Areas nationwide? In the prairie provinces, habitat management sometimes includes using carefully planned prescribed burning to restore or recreate natural habitat conditions and eradicate invasive species. In many grassland ecosystems, fire is a natural process – just like grazing – and is important for maintaining natural habitats for wildlife.....

What a cool blast from the past! Canadian Wildlife Service biologist Ron Mackay examines a Trumpeter Swan in the s. In , because of hunting and harassment, there were only Trumpeters in Canada and in the US. Today, as a result of an intensive international conservation effort, there are about wild Trumpeter Swans, and the species is no longer considered in danger of extinction......

It may not look like much but over the last year, scientists have been using these new solar-powered satellite transmitters to tag and track Thayer’s Gulls from the high arctic to BC. This data is helping scientists learn about the foraging and migrating behavior of this species, and how they overlap with areas of high marine shipping. Recently, a bird with a transmitter stopped moving. The signal remained strong, and coordinates indicated it was located in a remote area of Alaska. Scientists presumed the device lost until a local resident offered to help with the search. Equipped with his boat, GPS, and coordinates provided by ECCC, he found the transmitter on a remote beach off of Iyoukeen Bay – km from ! Thanks Mr. Chew!.....

A Swainson’s hawk was sitting on a fencepost, eating its prey (a northern pocket gopher) when I stopped well back to have a look. Although I used a telephoto lens and was trying not to bother it, after stripping off and gulping a few bits of meat from this headless snack, the hawk decided it wanted to nosh the rest without an audience, and took off (dramatically) to find a solitary perch.Swainson’s Hawks show up for our prescribed fires. Once the smoke starts rising, Swainson’s will be attracted to forage for mice/voles/shrews who have no more grass cover to hide in. We’ve seen as many as or hawks in one area that has been recently burned.Over species (301 at the last official count) use the Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area for breeding (180 species) and passing through on migration.People like Kerry monitor nesting success of these large hawks at the LML NWA. Come and see for yourself at our open house June -6pm....

Today is all about connecting people to nature! Nature surrounds us and World Environment Day reminds us to take action to conserve and protect our natural environment. Breathe in the beauty and remember that by keeping our planet healthy, we keep ourselves healthy too.Even as scientists discover new species (estimates suggest millions remain unknown), it is clear that our biodiversity is under threat – from competing land uses, pollution, population growth and human activities.We’re working with partners to conserve our biodiversity.....WorldEnvironmentDay

years ago, his Royal Highness Prince Philip celebrated the Centennial of Last Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary.In , Last Mountain Lake was set aside for the conservation of birds, a historic decision and the first of its kind in North America. Meet our Conservation Biologists Karen and Julie and Wildlife Enforcement Officer Ryan. They’re at Halifax’s McNabs Island, home to one of Nova Scotia’s biggest barn swallow colonies. Although barn swallows are one of the world’s most widespread and common land bird species, populations in Canada have declined by % since the s. Karen and her colleagues are busy carefully checking up on breeding and nesting barn swallows, making sure these aerial insectivores are able to breed and raise their babies undisturbed by Island visitors.....

Boot Island is located in the upper Bay of Fundy so when Andrew and Garry, from the Canadian Wildlife Service visited the island to improve the signage, they had to time their trip carefully to avoid hauling the Zodiac over hundreds of meters of mud. It’s that fieldwork time of year for our shorebirds biologist, Jennie, who is currently in Kugluktuk, Nunavut along with volunteers for the Arctic Program for Regional and International Shorebird Monitoring (Arctic PRISM)! They will then be moving to the land near Tree River, Back-Hermann River and finally Igloolik.The Program for Regional and International Shorebird Monitoring (PRISM) was designed by biologists and researchers from the Canadian and United States Governments (Canadian Wildlife Service, U.S. Geological Survey and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service) to address concerns about shorebird population declines first noted on migration surveys.....
()・・・After yesterday's snow storm it was a crazy 'wading through snow' plot day today surveying birds! What a bad day to be a spider on white snow! 🤷‍️....

The cloud pictured is called a supercell thunderstorm. Supercell thunderstorms have a rotating updraft, and are almost always associated with severe weather. They often look like a barber pole or in some cases, a UFO!....: Kyle Fougere

These photos were taken during the Piping Plover census that takes place every five years throughout its breeding range which in Canada includes the prairies, Great Lakes, Quebec and Atlantic Canada. In this set of pictures Andrew and Garry spent the day on Shediac Island which is off the coast of New Brunswick in the Northumberland Strait. Even though they were in good habitat, they didn’t find Piping Plovers but there were a few Least Sandpipers kicking around!! ..... : Garry Donaldson

We have a season-long program on Country Island, Nova Scotia to protect the Roseate Tern colony and assess their productivity. One of the biggest jobs each season is to count the number of active Tern nests and in order to do that we usually bring a few extra people onto the island because of the number of nests and the fact that they’re often in challenging vegetation and so hard to see!! This means, all hands on deck …even directors and managers go on field trips! With views like these, who wouldn’t like to get out in the field to work? Yes CWS, the social media team is extremely jealous.... : Garry Donaldson

Did you know that endangered species conservation is sometimes complex and multi-national? This endangered burrowing owl was fitted with a satellite transmitter near her nest in Alberta in . The solar-powered transmitter allows scientists with the Canadian Wildlife Service and project collaborators to track her movements wherever she goes. After leaving her burrow in Alberta this bird flew over ,500km to winter in Central Mexico. In spring she returned to Alberta and nested less than km from where she was first captured. She was recently sighted by biologists in Mexico in the same wintering site as the year before, and we are hoping she makes a safe and successful return to Canada to raise the next generation of owls. 🦉....

The clouds ️ pictured are called mammatus. Mammatus are formed from outpouching of water vapour high in the atmosphere. They are often (but not always) seen in the anvil of strong thunderstorms, as was the case on this summer day!.... : Kyle Fougere

!Here’s Lynne, a biologist with the Canadian Wildlife Service, admiring this Weidemeyer’s while collecting genetic samples to help conserve the species. The Weidemeyer’s Admiral is a large butterfly that is only known in Canada from a small geographic area of southeastern Alberta. The species is listed as Special Concern under Canada’s Species at Risk Act, and little is known about the Canadian population. Cool fact: males of the species are territorial – they patrol and defend an area from all intruders.....
to when our dive crew performed Fall maintenance on the Wolfe Island Water Quality Monitoring Site on the St. Lawrence. Brrr......

On this photo, Josh is dusting it up at Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area (NWA) in Saskatchewan. This biologist is helping to restore migratory bird and wildlife habitat by seeding native prairie grasses and wildflowers. Not far down the road is biologist Denise, checking her progress as she tends to a young restoration area. Mowing reduces weeds and help new grassland plants to thrive! Soon enough these areas will be teeming with Savannah Sparrows, Deer Mice, Red-Backed Voles, Swainson’s and Red-Tailed Hawks.....
・・・Purple Sandpiper eggs! Found them by accident
We’ve come a long way with weather maps in the Meteorological Service of Canada; however, it’s still similar enough to be recognizable as a weather map. Cheers to years of Canadian Weather.....

Meet wildlife biologist Sabina and wildlife technician Regina. Their work focuses on conserving and protecting seabirds, some of which are at-risk. Recently an apparently injured Northern Fulmar seabird was found on an offshore support vessel near Newfoundland and Labrador. The fulmar features large black eyes and a striking short, tube-like beak and resembles a gull; however it is actually related to the albatross and shearwater. It breeds in a few dozen scattered locations off Alaska and Canada, but is more abundant in the northeast Atlantic. Once the bird was delivered to the Canadian Wildlife Service lab, Sabina and Regina examined it, determined that it wasn’t injured, and decided it was ready for release. They took it to Witless Bay where a small colony of other fulmars breeds on three islands in the area. They watched the bird drink and vigorously bathe until it swam out of range toward the mouth of the bay. We’re excited about this happy ending!....

How do you tag a snail? With nail polish, of course! And when you go back to recapture them a few days later, don’t be surprised if they’ve moved a surprisingly long way away.This Oregon Forest Snail is red-listed in BC and only found in sites in the southwest. Canadian Wildlife Service biologists were doing a mark-recapture study to determine habitat type and snail presence in one of the sites. It was a good chance to practice nail polish application skills, and a lesson learned in how to minimize the effects of stinging nettle!Sometimes, you meet other friends, like this Northwestern Salamander, along the way.....

News from Biologist Jennie Rausch ・・・Another field season comes to a close for half of the team {the Nanuit Itillinga (Polar Bear Pass) National Wildlife Area Tier2/intensive camp crew is still out until the end of July}. Ending off the Tier1/rapid crew posts with selfie montages!
Is this the look for fall ?Coop student Lara is trying on a set of caribou antlers found on the tundra, during bird surveys last summer. ....

We have our own little recording studio in the field! Well, not quite, but almost… We’re using song meters to monitor and record Common Nighthawk activity. Song meters are preprogrammed and set to record from dusk until dawn. Here is Regina, retrieving song meters at the end of the season.....

Here’s biologist Kerry, reporting from the field at Last Mountain Lake NWA. While the wildflowers were thriving, this -year-old restoration site needed, and still needs a helping hand. Her plan was to *inter-seed native prairie grasses, and here she was deciding which species and in what amounts. Her team sowed and mowed over the course of the season, and soon there will be a sea of grasses for the birds and wildlife to live in! *Inter- seeding yields a mixture of grasses and legumes/forbs that gives the fullest benefit for wildlife or forage for livestock. It’s a good way to improve existing stands of single species grasses on fields utilized for pasture, wildlife, or idle land.....
! !Red-throated Loons are soooo pretty with their soft grey heads and bright red eye. They are also soooo good at staying perfectly still when they see a threat..... …

Species at Risk Biologist Andrew, Canadian Wildlife Service, Prairie Region, handling a large male prairie rattlesnake as part of reptile and amphibian conservation studies at Suffield National Wildlife Area, Alberta.....

Arctic goose banding occurs in July and August each year, during a brief period when geese are flightless, while they replace their flight feathers. Individually numbered aluminum leg bands are attached to the birds and they are released. Subsequent encounters from hunters across North America provide information about population size, migration routes and survival of the birds and this information is critical to ensuring the long term sustainability of these species. Here, a banding crew joined force with a helicopter to herd snow geese toward a net for banding on Southampton Island, Nunavut. Garth Ball....

This photo shows a small flock of Atlantic brant that have been successfully herded into a net for banding. Did you know you can contribute to these conservation efforts by reporting bird bands? The success of the bird banding program relies on reports of bird bands from the public. Data from recovered bands are essential for our researchers! Bands identify individual birds so that we can better understand their movements and it provides us with important information for managing bird populations. Garth Ball....

I flew higher than the sky years ago but I am no bird. Who am I? Dr. Roberta Bondar, the first Canadian female astronaut!Dr. Bondar joined Becky from Canadian Wildlife Service and other researchers on Country Island to capture the beauties of this spectacular place. Connecting people with nature through arts is now among her goals with the Roberta Bondar Foundation.Only km offshore of Guysborough County NS, this little island is home to the largest known colony of Roseate Terns in Canada.....

Roseate Terns like to nest in places with a bit of overhead cover to help protect them from birds like gulls and ravens that may steal their eggs. This might include spaces under rocks or vegetation, but they also might take advantage of a man-made shelter like this one. Biologists on Country Island keep an eye on them to watch their progress in laying their eggs, incubating, and feeding the chicks until they fledge. The marker R401 identifies the nest for the records. Garry Donaldson....
No you’re not seeing double, these are twin calves captured by one of our Reconyx cams! We use motion-sensor cameras to photograph wildlife in their natural habitats.....

Symbol of E , the sphere designed by visionary architect Buckminster Fuller holds an important place in the history of contemporary architecture. Since , the Biosphère is a site devoted to environmental action and education.The museum distinguishes itself by its interactive and educational exhibits as well as animated activities which are aimed at increasing understanding of major environmental issues such as air, water, biodiversity, climate change, sustainable development and more.In fact, this unique structure uses a number of green technologies: wind turbines, green roof systems, a geothermal system, wastewater treatment wetlands and solar panels.....

Here’s our friend Todd on Kejimkujik Lake, Nova Scotia sampling mercury concentrations in water, sediments and fish in support of the Clean Air Regulatory Agenda.The Clean Air Regulatory Agenda (CARA) was established in to support Government of Canada efforts to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) and air pollutant emissions in order to improve the environment and health of Canadians.....
“Do you think it saw me? Maybe I should work on my camouflage skills eh?” This coyote thought it could escape our Reconyx cam at Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area but it didn’t!....

We use helicopters to help us move around the arctic to our study sites, so that we can record all the birds we find and the type of habitats they are using during the short breeding season.....

The Reference Climate Station at Fort Vermillion was due for its annual inspection to ensure our sensors were within tolerance and the system was in full operational condition. After the lengthy hour drive to Fort Vermillion, the crew was glad the weather was cooperative the following day.This site is located at the Mackenzie Applied Research Association, which conducts numerous crop related research. We were on site for roughly hours as there were several sensors that were out of tolerance and we had to replace them including our rate of rainfall, and precipitation sensors. This site is one of a few we have in Alberta that also measure soil temperatures and soil moisture. However prior to arrival the soil moisture sensors were not working. After an hour of troubleshooting and rewiring we were able to get the majority of the sensors functioning. Braden Bunce....

“You Moose tell me, is this my good side?” This young calf was hanging at Meanook National Wildlife Area (NWA) in Alberta.NWAs are protected and managed according to the Wildlife Area Regulations under the Canada Wildlife Act. Their primary purpose is the protection and conservation of wildlife and their habitat!....

What is the first thing you think of when we say Arctic?Polar bears!As the Arctic Eedition embarks on their adventure we wonder if they will spot a polar bear. We work with its international partners, NGO’s and other governments, to conserve this incredible species..... Photo : Garry Donaldson

Today we’re celebrating years of bird conservation! In , the United States and Canada signed the Migratory Birds Convention- a pledge to protect Migratory Birds. In , the Migratory Birds Convention Act was hatched and it became law! Since then, nearly birds have been protected and studied, to help sustain biodiversity, and to further understanding of the health of our environment....

The Canadian Hurricane Centre is celebrating years! In Hurricane Gloria was approaching the Maritime provinces but much of the info was focused on US impacts. The need for Canada-focused information eventually led to the creation of the CHC in . The Centre now operates out of Dartmouth, NS and services all Canadian territory and waters that can be affected by tropical cyclones.....

Mission Monarch monitoring is officially underway at Long Point, Prince Edward Point and St. Clair National Wildlife Areas for this summer!In an effort to implement conservation measures under the Monarch management plan, Environment and Climate Change Canada staff and volunteers are heading out to the National Wildlife Areas to look for and report sightings of Monarch eggs, caterpillars, and adult butterflies.You can help! Join Mission Monarch and report milkweed and Monarch sightings in your area:

Yesterday was World Shorebird Day! It’s all about raising awareness of shorebirds! In our half of the world these long-distance migrants breed in the Arctic in May-August and winter in South America. They face numerous challenges on their journey so protecting the habitats they need to complete their annual cycle is a cooperation of governments, industries, scientists, volunteers and citizens throughout the western hemisphere (and the world!).....

Monarch enthusiasts found a tiny monarch caterpillar on a milkweed plant during a Mission Monarch workshop.We hosted the workshop which was hosted by the Montreal Insectarium at our Big Creek National Wildlife Area in July. This event had an amazing turnout, participants got to see presentations on the Monarch’s biology, threats and declines, and the details of the Mission Monarch monitoring protocol. Participants had the opportunity to practice what they learned on the property, where they were thrilled to find several milkweed plants with Monarch caterpillars and eggs....

We captured this wonderful moment during Canadian Wildlife Service’s First Annual Mentored Hunt, at Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area. Our participants learned so much about ethical and sustainable hunting from our wonderful mentors!With this event, we were able to show people that hunting waterfowl actually helps maintain the population in several ways. Snow Geese, for example, have a current population of over billion. Their nesting grounds are becoming so overpopulated that it is destroying the habitat for other wildlife in the region. Hunting not only helps maintain these populations, but also helps us raise money for conservation, restoration, and enhancement of wildlife habitat in Canada through the purchase of necessary documents such as the Canadian Wildlife Habitat Conservation Stamp.....

We are creating a souvenir album celebrating years of bird conservation in Canada! Share with us your bird anecdotes or thoughts on birds today! The album will contain testimonials and photos of people.Here’s how to participate :. During the breeding season, scientists with Canadian Wildlife Service and counted a record whooping crane chicks in and around Wood Buffalo National Park – a substantial and encouraging increase over the previous record of in . Monitoring efforts now switch from boreal breeding areas to Saskatchewan’s parkland and prairie regions, where migrating whooping cranes stop for up to six weeks before continuing their journey to wintering grounds along the Texas Gulf Coast. We ask that anyone observing this endangered species to call the Whooping Crane Hotline at (306) -5595 : John Conkin ....

Canada’s national wildlife areas (NWA) are created and managed for wildlife conservation, research and interpretation purposes under the Canada Wildlife Act and in accordance to the Wildlife Area Regulations. For many reasons, but primarily to facilitate the administration of national wildlife areas, we are currently considering amendments to the regulations to modernize them. We want to hear from YOU! Canadian Wildlife Service Species at Risk biologist, Dr. Wellicome, trains a field technician to use a scope to view the underground nest of a Burrowing Owl. The scope feeds live infrared video to a pair of goggles, allowing the user to count how many adult owls, owlets, eggs, and cached prey are inside the burrow. Using a hood helps block out daylight glare to get a clearer image in the gOWLggles.: Danielle Todd...

Guess what? We built two “supersites” in Iqaluit and Whitehorse! A supersite has a variety of weather instruments that allow scientists to measure atmospheric conditions in detail. For people living in the North, information like the temperature and humidity isn’t as important as they are in the South. Knowing about blowing snow and ice-fog (a fog made up of small ice crystals suspended in the air!) are much more relevant! The new sites will help us understand what weather instruments will work best, so that we can improve weather forecasts in the North....

Update: We are in the final steps towards producing improved weather forecasts in the North! Backing our weather radar onto its site in Whitehorse was a bit of a tight squeeze! Soon, we will be able to transmit the first data....

Julie and a number of Canadian Wildlife Service biologists from our Sackville, New Brunswick office were in the field last week helping out with the annual Cape Tormentine Christmas Bird Count. The annual Count is one of the largest citizen science projects in North America; the results help provide information about the status of bird populations. These brave employees faced brisk arctic-like winds to record different species! :Garry Donaldson...

David Phillips, senior meteorologist at Environment and Climate Change Canada, calls “the year of too much” – the weather across the country was either too dry, too hot, or too wet. He’s compiled his annual list of the Top Ten Weather Stories in Canada during . His list includes everything from catastrophic wildfires in British Columbia to severe winter storms in the Atlantic provinces. “The increased severity of our weather is certainly consistent with our eectations of rising global temperatures,” Phillips says. “This list demonstrates that our communities must become more resilient to the effects of climate change.”...

Do you remember me? Back in April, we held a contest to give me a name! I am a Common Loon and the mascot of the Canadian Wildlife Service here at Environment and Climate Change Canada. You suggested lots of great names. I chose “Kwimu,” which means “spirit bird” in many Indigenous languages. Since the name “Tuuli” was also very popular, I decided to give this name to the chick that I carry on my back. Tuuli means loon in Inuktitut. Thanks for participating! ...

It’s Arctic Science Month! Cheryl is a wildlife scientist here at Environment and Climate Change Canada. Together with her team, Indigenous knowledge and innovative research techniques are combined to understand how changing snow and ice conditions – driven by climate change – affect the habitat of the Peary Caribou, which lives in the high arctic, and is considered endangered in Canada. ...

During Arctic Science Month, we’re proud to highlight the important research by our scientists working to better understand the impacts of climate change on the habitats of migratory birds – like Ross’s geese and king eider ducks – that breed in Canada’s northern regions....

“It was near sunset when we finally finished the annual maintenance at a remote weather station near Bathurst Inlet in Nunavut. The warm light of the sun showing off the natural vegetation and our ride home on a small landing strip near our station.” – Braden Bunce: Braden Bunce...

Summer throwback! In these photos, Hannah and Paul, graduate students from Dr. Koper’s lab at the University of Manitoba, are collaborating with Barry, an employee of the Canadian Wildlife Service to monitor Baird’s Sparrow survival on breeding grounds outside of Brooks in southeastern Alberta. This project is part of a tri-national collaboration between Canada, the USA, and Mexico, with the goal of determining where and when the bird is most limited: on the breeding grounds in Canada and the USA, or the wintering grounds in Mexico. To monitor survival, we are deploying tiny Very High Frequency (VHF) transmitters in Alberta, while our partners at the Bird Conservancy of the Rockies deploy transmitters in Montana, North Dakota and Mexico. ...

Would you believe these pictures were taken back to back? One of our scientists working at the Eureka Weather Station in Eureka, Nunavut, went for a morning walk. Due to the moon being in its waning phase, the sun and the moon were clearly visible at the same time. The waning moon rises during the night, is visible in the morning, and sets during the day. After capturing this cool shot of a muskox and the moon, she turned around and saw a beautiful sunrise. : Renee Cossitt....

Our scientists went to Tuktut Nogait National Park in the Northwest Territories to conduct some annual maintenance and upgrades on an automatic weather station this summer. After the work was done, their helicopter flew them to the beautiful La Roncière Waterfalls. .canada : Braden Bunce...

cliffLAND: “…where nature remains wild and self-willed, ministering to our need for beauty and inspiration," - Howard Clifford. cliffLAND Conservation Area is owned by the Clifford Family and is a special piece of the Canadian Shield that meets the limestone of the east and south. It is made unique by an underlay of marble that produces an incredible richness of biodiversity. A Canada plaque is being installed on this property to honour the donor’s conservation efforts. cliffLAND was donated as part of Environment and Climate Change Canada’s Ecological Gifts program, and is forever protected by the Mississippi Madawaska Land Trust. The Ecological Gifts Program offers tax benefits to landowners who donate land to be preserved for the rest of time....
